ROBERT FIELD: This lecture is
about pure rotation spectra, and this is a pretty
standard topic.

And what I'm going
to try to do is to move as quickly
as possible towards

the non-standard aspects.  In a textbook, you'll
read all sorts of stuff

about what are the rules
and what are the formulas, and it really doesn't address
the question of what are we

really trying to do? When we're faced
with a spectrum, the first thing we
have to do is assign it, and the next thing we do--

or maybe at the same
time as we assign it, we're trying to decide what
is the qualitative structure

of the molecule? What of several
possible symmetry groups

it could belong to. And sometimes, you can't
do one without the other.

You can't assign the
spectrum until you have an idea of what the
qualitative structure

of the molecule is, and
then of course the goal is to get as much
information as possible

about the actual structure. Now, what's never
in the textbooks

is, OK, what are the things
in the spectrum that you look for when it's not obvious
how to sort things out.

And there are
selection rules that

correspond to the changes
of the quantum numbers

that we keep track
of, and depending on what the structure
of the molecule

is, what the qualitative
structure of the molecule is, you can know something about
what will these selection
rules be.

The asymmetry splittings
or the presence of asymmetry doublings
in the spectrum

is an extremely important
piece of information.

They're large when
J minus K is large.

And the lower level is
always the level where--

I mean the higher level. Higher component is when
J is equal to KA plus KC.

Often, there's a thing
called an inertial defect.

That is something that
you look for if you
think the molecule is planar. Molecules that are planar--

molecules that are planar have
a very small inertial defect.

If they were
rigidly planar, they would have a zero
inertial defect.

Another thing that
you worry about is permutation
symmetry restrictions

and nuclear statistical weights. This is an incredibly
subtle and difficult point.

So if you're going to
be a real microwave spectroscopist or any
kind of spectroscopist,

you are going to
have to learn how to deal with things like this.

Remember, in a course on
statistical mechanics,

you classified the
rotational levels of hydrogen into ortho and para levels
and similarly for oxygen.

And some interesting
things resulted.

Now, rotations per
minute identical atoms.

And so a proper understanding
of rotational spectra

is going to require
understanding of permutation symmetries,
and then it's subtle.

All I need to do is say, OK,
what about acetylene, where you have two carbons, which
are spineless and two hydrogens

that have spin in half. And so if we just rotate
the molecule by 180 degrees,

you've permuted to spineless
things and to spin things.

And so how do you even begin
to classify levels according
to permutation symmetry? What's missing?

The permutation
symmetries will enter into the rotational
spectrum in two ways.

One way is nuclear
statistical weights, just as they did in
the atomic spectra.

But you're going to have to
do something extra in order to even begin to write
the wave functions.

So they will result in an extra
weighting of certain levels,
according to nuclear symmetry-- nuclear degeneracy.

They will also result in
extra selection rules,

because photons are not going to
be able to flip nuclear spins.

And so nuclear symmetry-- the permutation
symmetries are going

to perhaps provide
restrictions on what transitions you can observe.

Fortunately, it is
very rare, except when you're dealing with very
complicated large amplitude

motions and internal rotations
that the permutation symmetries
give you anything about--

give you any additional
selection rules beyond what you get
simply by asking where is the dipole moment
pointing in the body axis?

But whenever you get
away from textbook cases, the permutation symmetries
are going to be the truth,

and they will give
extra selection rules.

Why do I say this? When you have internal motions
that permute molecules,

what ends up happening-- permute identical atom. What ends up happening
is that degeneracies

to which you normally had
not even known we're there, it lifted. And it's the transitions
among these levels

with that unsuspected
degeneracies lifted that you need the extra
selection rules for.

So this is just a
little bit of a warning about the non-textbook
stuff that I won't have time

to deal with properly,
but you don't want to just accept this as
a simple problem of assigning

rotational spectra
that you can just look in a textbook and
everything you need to know.

And just asking about
the permutation symmetry of a molecule as
simple as acetylene

is a warning that there's
big subtleties there.

AUDIENCE: Can I ask the question
about rotation symmetry? ROBERT FIELD: Yes. AUDIENCE: Is there any advantage
to doing simultaneous NMR

in microwave spectroscopy? ROBERT FIELD: Well, NMR
is not very sensitive.

And so doing NMR on gas
phase molecules is hard. AUDIENCE: Well, what
if you're not really

using the NMR to learn
something about the NMR signal. What you're trying
to flip spins or--

ROBERT FIELD: Well, you want
to do a radial frequency microwave double resonance
kind of experiment.

You can do that. AUDIENCE: Has that been done? ROBERT FIELD:
Yeah, I've done it. But I haven't done
magnetic dipole.

AUDIENCE: So you don't
have a static field on it you, just use an RF pulse to--

ROBERT FIELD: You can-- AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]. ROBERT FIELD: You
can use an RF pulse, or you can use a CW RF field
and you can cause transmissions

among hyperfine components. And these additional--
I mean, double resonance

is always going to be useful. And again, the
problem is that when

you think about
magnetic resonance you're doing magnetic
dipole transitions, and those are weaker than
electric dipole transitions.

But you can use any
kind of double resonance to label any subset
of levels you want,

and so it can be
a valuable thing. But I don't have anything
more to say on the subject.

AUDIENCE: Do more
machines can do gas phase in a more spectra that are--

ROBERT FIELD: Well, just ask,
what is the relative density of a liquid versus a gas?

And even when people
do biological NMR,

they put a milligram and or
maybe less than a milligram

of material. When you scale that to the gas
phase, how many molecules--

how many biological
molecules they have in that tube
compared to how many diatomic molecules in
the gas phase in that volume?

And you discover that there is
a considerable disadvantage.

It is possible, and
[INAUDIBLE] do NMR on S4,

and this was pretty primitive. This was in the late
'50s, or early '60s, or something like that.
So it's possible.

So then additional information
from isotopes and hot bands.

So there are all
sorts of things that

go into sorting out a spectrum,
and the standard sterilized

version of pure rotation
spectroscopy you will find in almost any book
really hides what's

really beautiful and difficult
and still challenging

more than 70 years after the
first microwave spectra were
recorded.  OK, so let's begin.
Oh, one more little thing.

There are lots of tricks
for assigning spectra. The oldest one is
stark modulation.

But the more new ones are
double resonance and things

called extended spectral
cross-correlation.

I mean, stark modulation,
certain levels are very sensitive to
applied electric field

and particularly levels with
low K but not K equals 0.

And double resonance,
there's a zillion kinds of double resonance. Sam has already suggested one,
and extended cross correlation

is especially valuable
for sorting a spectrum

into different chemical species
or different isotopomers.

And it's an appropriate topic
to mention before we really

get into the formal stuff. Now, because with
chirped pulse techniques,

you can record a
microwave spectrum that has a lot of peaks in it.

A lot of transitions. In the old days, you
scan for the entire range

of what equipment
you have available and you see a few transitions.

You don't see
enough of a pattern in order to do very much
sophisticated pattern

recognition. You have to know
what's there and you have to calculate what the
spectrum would be and then see

whether the little
fragments that you can see are consistent with
what you expect.

When there are lots of
lines in your spectrum, you can develop new
strategies for sorting them.

For example, if you
record a spectrum and you don't know whether
it's only one molecule present,

I mean one species present,
you can spike the system--

spike the mixture with a
molecule you think is present

or spike it with and with
a different isotopomer.

And this
cross-correlation method will pull out because
you have spectra

with meaningful
intensities, and the pattern of intensities
for one feature is

going to be the same from
one spectrum to the other. By changing the
relative amounts,

the cross correlation
will tell you which features go
with which molecules.

So there are a lot of really
clever things still possible, and now, we'll start in
on the standard material.

So we had some
unfinished business

starting on the top of page
5 of lecture number 23. We have a rotational
Hamiltonian,

which we can write
in general form B bar
JJ plus 1 plus A minus B bar.

I think that's
probably right or C--

that can't be right. Well, I'm going to
write it this way.
K squared.
And then we have the--

so we can write the
Hamiltonian in a general form, which is appropriate for either
the prolate or oblate limits.

And so we have
the diagonal part,

and so if we've chosen a prolate
top based asset, we use this

and we use the top
here, and these are the off diagonal parts. And the selection rules
are delta J equals 0 always

and delta K, whether it's KA or
KC is equal to 0 plus or minus

2. There's a change of
K by an even number.

So this matrix has a
structure, where only--

you can factor the matrix into
a block, where you have only even K or only odd K. So that's
a rigorous factorization.

We have no connection
between even K and odd K.

Now, we can do
something further. Suppose we take the quantization
axis out of the plane

and we have some a reflection
plane through the quantization

axis. So that's generally
called a sigma view plane

because the quantization
axis is the z direction,

and so a reflection plane that
contains the quantization axis

is a vertical plane. Now-- and there's all sorts
of really beautiful mnemonics

for representing, not
just the positions of atoms in the molecule
but actually motions.

So suppose we have an atom over
here it's moving like this.

And an atom over here
that's moving like that.

Now, we apply this operation,
and this atom and its velocity vector gets switched like that.

And this one ends up
looking like that.

I should have used two
different pieces of chalk. So you can see that if there's
rotation about this axis,

this reflection reverses
the sense of rotation.

So that implies
that the sigma v is an operator that's
going to commute

with the rotational Hamiltonian. It's going to be
useful for classifying
the rotational levels. So we can write sigma B on J KM.

We know that sigma
v is going to take into the opposite side of K.

Now, we don't know what
it does to the sign,

but what we can do is we can
adopt the kondinin shortly

face convention unless somebody
tells us that that's wrong.

OK, so we can show
that sigma B commutes

with a rotational Hamiltonian. That means that we have to
write wave functions, which

are eigen functions of
the sigma B operator. If we don't, we can
diagonalize the Hamiltonian,

and we'll discover that the
functions of the Hamiltonian are automatically eigen
functions of the parity--

the sigma v operator. But sometimes, it helps. It helps, because
what it does is

it reduces the Hamiltonian now
from even K and odd K to even K

with two blocks and
odd K with two blocks. And those two blocks
are called parity,

and so we have taken
the Hamiltonian, and by constructing wave
functions of the form JKM

plus or minus J
minus KM, we have now

block diagnolized the
Hamiltonian into four blocks.

And there's a thing called
the Wang transformation, where the inverse transformation
is the same thing
as the transformation itself.

1 over square root of 2
minus times this big thing,

minus 1 along this diagonal
square root of 2 in the middle.

One down here,
one, one, one, one.

That's the Wang
transformation and if you

have your matrix
organized in the order K is equal to J 0 minus
J, well then that thing,

that transformation will
block diagonalized Hamiltonian into four blocks like that.

Now, remember the
correlation diagram. Say we have the prolate
limit here, 0, 1, 2, K.

KA, and over here, we have
the oblate limit through 1 2,
through KC. And we connected things up.
Uh oh, what did I do? Oh, see what I did.

OK, so we have
levels that have-- each of these is a
level, and each of these
is in the index by KA and KC.

And notice, here is
a level K equals 1,

and it connects to
KC equals 1 and 2.

We can classify
all of the levels according to whether
KA is even or odd.

And KC is even or odd. And there are four
possibilities.

And these actually
correspond to four symmetries

of the rotational group. So the four blocks
from the Hamiltonian

are going to be
labeled according to whether the values
of KA KC are even, even,

even, odd, odd,
even, and odd, odd. And these are four
separate species.

It doesn't matter what the
symmetry of the molecule is, the rotational Hamiltonian
has its own symmetry

and can always be
classified in this way.

So that's something
that bothers people. How can I be applying
sigma V to a wave function

for a molecule that doesn't
have a sigma V plane? Doesn't matter, the
rotational wave functions

do have such planes. So we classify the levels,
we have four symmetry labels,

and it's important
to remember always

that if you're using
the prolate bases, the KC quantum number is
not really a projection,

but it is definitely
either even or odd, and that's the important
thing, and that this

is a mnemonic for
getting everything right. And it's a mnemonic
also for getting

an idea of how big the
asymmetry splittings are.

And so you can put these
EO and these E and O labels on all of these levels.
And that's a real symmetry.
OK, so once we have now our--

we know that there are
levels of the asymmetric top, and we can label them
always with good J

and we can label them with
not such good KA and KC and with good EO labels
for the KA and KC.

So now, we want to move
on to considering, well, what does the transition--
what determines the transition

probabilities? And again, I've discovered
that in my notes,

I'm being a little bit naive,
but the transition probability is going to be always
written in a form like this.

Remember, these are
space fixed axes,

and these are body fixed axes. The electric field that we
detect is quantized in space,

and we have VI, and what's
now not in my notes,

and this is still doing
it this way is dishonest. We have the transition
moment operator

as a function of
coordinates and VF.

Sorry about that, and
then we square that. This is really-- these
states are really

sums over 0 order states. But I just want to make
this as simple as possible.

So if it's a pure rotation
transition, VF is equal to VI, and this thing this part reduces
to really a sum over basis

functions, but we
can represent them. It's just-- and
this is evaluated

at all of the displacement
coordinates equal to 0. So this is the permanent--

this is the permanent dipole
moment in the body frame. It's a vector, it has components
along the A, B, and C axes

in principle. And so what would you really
like to know is, well, what does this do?

What does this give rise to? What I've slipped
under the rug is that in order to
get these functions

we have to take a
linear combination of symmetric top functions.

But the symmetric top functions
have definite direction cosine matrix elements.

So you need to
worry about how does what's happening in the body
frame relate to the laboratory

frame, and that's
what this does. And this-- OK, so now,
we want to consider

what this matrix element is. Now, there's two
ways of doing this.

One is the way that
you'll remember and the other is the way
that is more fundamental.

You can do this by
just drawing a picture or you can do this
group theoretical sense.

I mean, suppose you
have a dipole moment.

You know that you can apply
an electric field somehow and you can torque
this dipole moment.

If the molecule has a dipole
moment only in one direction,

well, one thing you can't
do is twist it this way. You can't rotate about
the dipole moment.

You can only torque
perpendicular to the dipole moment.

And what that means is that
if there's a dipole moment in this direction.

You can add angular momentum
about directions perpendicular to the dipole moment.

OK, so we can talk about
three types of transitions.

And we call them A type,
B type, and C type.

If you have a dipole moment
along the A axis, well, KA can't change because
you can't do this.

So delta KA is 0, and
0 is an even number.

Remember, we have
off-diagonal elements,

and the K's mix
with even K's only.

So 0 is what you
expect, but you know that for A-type transitions,
delta KA will be even.

Principally, 0. And then KC will be plus or
minus 1 or more safely, odd.

And similarly, if it's
B-type, well, the B axis

is perpendicular to
both the A and C axes, so we have odd and odd.

And C type, well, this
is going to be 0 even,

and this is going to be odd.  So to be more specific,
we have EO, OO, and OE.

OK, so the three components
of a dipole momeny can give rise to changes
in KA and KC of this type.

And this is what you
will always remember. If you start with just
this picture of how

do you impart angular
momentum to the molecule, then you can
immediately write down

there will be three
types of transitions, and this is what they will do.

Now, there's one more
thing that you can remember from diatomic molecules. Remember, in diatomic
molecules, we

have parallel type
transitions, delta J

equals 0 transitions
are weak or absent,

and perpendicular, where
delta J equals 0 transitions, few branches are strong.

Usually, the strongest. And it's true here too that if
you have a near prolate top,

and you have A type transitions,
there won't be any Q branches.

Now, what's a Q branch? Remember, a Q branch-- the pure rotation
spectrum, a Q branch

would be a transition
between states of the same J,
and these will be small. These will be low frequency.

Transitions that
change J are generally what you observe
in the microwave,

but you can have Q
branch transitions. They are usually at
very low frequency,

but you can also have q
branches when you change K,

and those are
quite strong if you have a component of the
dipole moment perpendicular

to your near symmetry axis. Yes? AUDIENCE: For an
asymmetric top molecule,

the dipole moment doesn't have
to be along one of those axes, right? ROBERT FIELD: That's right. Well, but what you
do is resolve it

into components along
the various axes, and then what you discover is
that the different components

of the dipole give rise to
transition amplitudes that can interfere constructively
and destructively.

So you can-- AUDIENCE: Both A
type and B type. ROBERT FIELD: That's right. AUDIENCE: They're just
on top of each other.

ROBERT FIELD: That's right. So you have to be a
little bit careful,

because the different types
have different selection rules,

and sometimes,
you're out of luck.

But you can almost always
from interference effects

not only know that
there's A type-- there's an A and a B component
of the dipole but what

their relative signs are. So where is the dipole? And you know you
have to be able to do that because the
dipole definitely

has an orientation
in the body frame and you're asking
about something

that's happening in the
body frame transferred into the laboratory, but
that information is there.

You just have to
be clever about it. And one of the ways to get
at least a few extra people

to read one of your
papers is to talk about interference effects.

And this isn't the
way in which you learn about dipole moments
that have more than one

of the A, B, and
C type character. Is it through
interference effects?

That's gilding
the lily, but yes.

OK, so from this picture, we can
classify the various components

of the dipole operator
in terms of these labels.

And so now, we have a
transition matrix element,

and we have initial
states, J, KA, KC,

and we have final
states, J, KA, KC.

And in order for this integral
to be different from 0,

we have to have the KA
selection rules have to be--

if there's going to be a
change in KA that's odd, then the operator that does
it has to be odd with respect

to A. And if the change in KC is
odd, the operator has to have--

has to be odd with
respect to the C axis.

And so those are
the select rules, and you can work that out.

OK, so how are we
doing for time? Good.

So what do spectra
actually look like?

Well, the big disappointment is
that symmetric top spectra are really, really, really boring.

Because in a symmetric top, here
is the energy level diagram-- oops.

So for a symmetric top, this
is k equals 0, k equals 1, K equals 2.

The level structure doesn't
depend on K, it just--

as you go up in K, you're
missing lower levels. But the transitions--
I'm sorry.

There's always a
corresponding transition in each of the K stacks
unless K is too large.

And so all you can do is
observe transitions which

are delta J equals plus
or minus 1 delta K--

OK, now, how do we know this? If we have a
symmetric top, we can

prove that you need either
a C3 axis or two C2 axes.

I think we need
actually three in order to get a symmetric
top, but there are going to be rotation axes.

And for the usual KC3 or
higher, the quantization axis

is always along
the rotation axis. So that means you can
rotate the molecule.

If there's a dipole moment
perpendicular to the symmetry axis, well, that's impossible,
because if you rotate

the molecule by a
required symmetry angle,

it has to look identical
to the way it did before. And if there's a
perpendicular dipole,

you could tell
that you rotate it. So you can't have a
dipole perpendicular

to the symmetry axis. So prolate tops
have an A dipole.

That means delta K is 0. Oblate tops have a C dipole,
and that means the delta K is 0.

AUDIENCE: But
that's not true for an accidental symmetric top.

ROBERT FIELD: Yeah, you can have
an accidental symmetric top, and I'm not prepared to
make generalizations,

because I only recently
discovered ways to make accidental symmetric
tops, but let's just do this.

I mean, we have a sys bent thing
and we're making a torsion.

So there's clearly a dipole
moment in this direction.

There's no dipole moment in that
direction or in that direction.

So what did that do? So what ends up happening
is that if you start sys

and you torsion, the dipole
moment axis doesn't move.

So you don't get anything
new, but there are probably cases where you might. So I haven't thought
that through.

That's a wonderful question. But the problem is that
neglecting subtle things
like centrifugal distortion.

You can't-- all you see is
diatomic light transitions.

Now, what does
centrifugal distortion do? We know that the
centrifugal distortion will give rise will have a term
like DJ A J plus 1 squared.

That's diatomic and that
doesn't care about K. And then it will have ADK, and
that does give K splittings,

and then there's
a crossover DJK, which is a JJ plus 1 squared.

And that will also give
a little splitting. So there is a little--

can be a little bit of structure
that appears in asymmetric top.

And symmetric top
spectra that's arises from centrifugal distortion.
But doesn't tell you anything.

You get B, and the
centrifugal distortion doesn't tell you anything
about A or C. So you get--

from analysis of
symmetric top spectrum, you get 1 rotational constant.

In the notes, there's
detailed discussion of NO2, and what I think would
be a useful thing

to do if I had more
time in the lecture is to do everything I did
for NO2 for a simple molecule

like formaldehyde. So formaldehyde has a
structure like this.
It clearly has a dipole moment. It's not a symmetric top.

It has a dipole moment along,
so it's a near prolate top,

and it has a dipole moment
along the A axis only.
So that means that it willl--

the selection rule for
KA and KC is even, odd.

And so there will
be transitions,
where delta KA is even.

That's one selection
rule, and that's too bad.

And delta KC is
odd, and so you'll

have transitions
within a manifold--

within a K manifold, where the
asymmetry component switches.

But because you can have
delta KA equals even, there are going to be some
delta KA equals 2 transitions.

It'll be weak, and
so that will give you some information about the
asymmetry parameter, which is--

I'm sorry. That will give you information
about the A inertial constant.

The transitions where you
change the asymmetry component will give you information
about B minus C,

and the dominant
transitions give you information about B
bar, which is B plus C2.

So you can get everything
you need in order

to get A, B, and C
for formaldehyde.

And then there's the issue is
formaldehyde planar or not? And this is actually
not a trivial issue,

because the excited
state is not planar.  The excited state is bent,
but the barrier is very low.

And so with a little bit of
autoplane bending exhortation, it will start acting
as if it were a planar

molecule, or at
least it would acting as if it's a molecule that is
a planar equilibrium geometry.

And so that brings
us to the last point that I want to touch on,
which is the inertial defect.

So if you have a planar
molecule, so these are the--

so these are the inertial axes. We have one axis
out of the plane,

and so suppose you
have an atom here.

So what you want is to know
the perpendicular distances

from the symmetry
axes, and so if you

have two of those
perpendicular distances, then you know that the
square of this distance plus the square of
that distance is

equal to the square
of this distance. And so for a planar
molecule, all of the atoms

follow this rule. And so that means that
1 over A plus 1 over B

is going to be
equal to 1 over C. That's the inertial defect or
1 over A plus 1 over B minus 1

over C is called
the inertial defect, and that should be nearly
0 for a planar molecule.

But it won't be exactly 0,
because the molecules are not rigid.

Now, there's a lot of very
beautiful stuff, again, by Watson about the meaning
of inertial defects.

and there's another sign
which is not acceptable. But if you have a
planar molecule,

you only get two
independent pieces of information, not three.

And so maybe I should
stop now, and so I

hope that I've given a
little bit of a sense of what are some of the
non-standard things that

go into rotational spectrum. I'm not sure what
the next topic is. It's probably vibration of
atomics, and so we're all set.
Thank you.
